snippet: After the Obama administration began airstrikes against ISIS near Kurdistan, some Iraqi politicians said the U.S. was more concerned about protecting the Kurds than Iraq’s Arab majority.
abstract: Victory by Kurdish and Yazidi militias in Sinjar, Iraq, over Islamic State fighters is bright spot for United States-led coalition, but it may prove to be detrimental to US relations with Iraqi government in Baghdad; many political leaders in Baghdad are concerned about unity of country and degree to which they can depend on US.

byline.contributor: Omar al-Jawoshy and Falih Hassan contributed reporting from Baghdad, and Andrew E. Kramer from Moscow.

lead_paragraph: After the Obama administration began airstrikes against ISIS near Kurdistan, some Iraqi politicians said the U.S. was more concerned about protecting the Kurds than Iraq’s Arab majority.

headline.main: Sinjar Victory Bolsters Kurds, but Could Further Alienate U.S. From Iraq
headline.print_headline: Victory Bolsters Kurds, but Not U.S.-Iraq Ties

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
